Like most of Akita, a car very convenient.  While there are some buses, they run infrequently and may be impractical.

value: directions=From the Akagami Shrine, walk up the 999 Stone Stairs.
content=This set of five shrines overlooks the coastline.
content=This shrine is the starting point for the hike to Goshado.
alt=男鹿市役所 なまはげ館
directions=Go generally west by car from Oganaka.  There are many zigzagging roads, so use a map.
content=This is a museum about namahage, the demons that scare children in Akita every New Year's Eve.
hours=Mar-Oct 9AM-5PM, Nov-Feb 9AM-4PM, Golden Week and Obon 8:30AM-6PM
directions=Start at either the Akagami Shrine or the Namahage Museum.

content=This hiking trail goes from the Akagami Shrine to the Namahage Museum.  It goes near the summit of Mt. Honzan (本山), which makes for a short side venture.  The trail takes around 4 hours, one way, and bus service at either end is infrequent.
content=This namahage performance involves demons coming down from the forest to scare children.  There is also dancing, drumming, and mochi throwing.
alt=宮沢海岸オートキャンプ場キャンパルわかみ
price=Car sites for ¥6,000 per site; non-car sites for ¥4,000 per site; open camping area for ¥2,000 per tent
content=This resort and campground is rather expensive, but it is well-situated on the beach in northern Oga.  There are campsites and cabins, and also an onsen for bathing.

is just to the SE.  From Akita, there are many travel options in and out of the prefecture.
